thread.title: Malone, Liberty Global in talks with U.K.-based cable firm
thread.title_full: Malone, Liberty Global in talks with U.K.-based cable firm

title: Malone, Liberty Global in talks with U.K.-based cable firm
text:
Allen & Co.'s Sun Valley conference kicks off this week. John Malone, chairman of Liberty Media Corp., arrives to a morning session at Conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, U.S., on Friday, July 12, 2013. Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg (Photo: Scott Eells, Bloomberg)
4 CONNECT 25 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Cable titan John Malone is looking to expand his global networking reach.
Liberty Global , the company chaired by Malone, confirmed that it is in talks to possibly buy U.K. based Cable & Wireless Communications , which delivers pay TV, voice, mobile and broadband connectivity in the Caribbean.
The deal could be worth more than $5 billion, according to a report in the Wall Street Journal , which first reported the deal citing unnamed sources.
Cable & Wireless has more than 5 million customers across its various operations. Liberty has more than 27 million customers in 14 countries in the U.K, Europe and Latin America.
"It's all about global scale. If you want to be a meaningful player in most of any of these media communication businesses, you have to think about it," Malone told CNBC back in May.
USA TODAY
John Malone: A cable pioneer back in the game
Malone is looking to expand in the U.S., too. Earlier this year, Charter Communications offered to buy Time Warner Cable for $55 billion. Liberty is the largest shareholder of Charter. Federal regulators are reviewing the deal.
This Cable & Wireless move is another sign that Malone is always looking for ways to expand, says Recon Analytics analyst Roger Entner. "And it's a relatively low-risk endeavor" that will "gain them a lot of learning in the challenges that traditional customers are facing."
Follow Mike Snider on Twitter: @MikeSnider
